column2: is a city of Sialkot District  in the Punjab province of Pakistan. The city is the capital of Pasrur Tehsil and is administratively subdivided into 26 wards of municipal committee Pasrur.It is located at 32°16'0N 74°40'0E with an altitude of 238 metres (784 feet). The nearest big cities are Sialkot
column3: Narowal and Gujranwala. It contains a village called Nawan Sohawa.

column1: Nearby are the remains of a bridge built by Shah Daula.

column2: Pasrur became the headquarters of Pasrur Tehsil. The town (which lies 18 miles south of the district capital Sialkot) lies on the Sialkot to Amritsar road. The population in 1901 was 8
column3: 335. The trade of Pasrur has become very decayed
column4: partly through the opening of the North-Western Railway and partly on account of the octroi duties which have diverted trade to the neighboring village of Saukin Wind. Hand-printed cotton stuffs were the only manufacture of importance.

column1: The municipality was created in 1867. The income during the ten years ending 1902-3 averaged Rs. 7
column6: chiefly from octroi ; and the expenditure was Rs. 6
column7: 900. The town had an Anglo-vernacular high school maintained by the District board
